FRCDesign.org 2025-2026 Season Updates

Thank you for all the support in the past season! We have several updates coming this offseason and want to share more about them.

Roadmap

  1. Stage 1A Update Published
  2. Stage 2 Rework
  3. FRCDesignLib finished
  4. FRCDesignApp Beta

FRCDesignLib:
Work on FRCDesignLib is coming along great, we should meet our original goal of releasing the library out of Beta before the upcoming season starts. If you don‚Äôt already have access to the library, fill out this form to gain access.

FRCDesignApp:
We have started development on a new Onshape app to hopefully improve the way users interact with FRCDesignLib. We are hoping to have a beta release of this app for testing sometime this offseason as well.

Links

Main Site:

frcdesign.org

FRCDesign.org

A comprehensive learning guide and technical reference for FRC design using Onshape.

Dev Site:

dev.frcdesign.org

FRCDesign.org

A comprehensive learning guide and technical reference for FRC design using Onshape.

FRCDesignLib Access Form:

Google Docs

FRCDesignLib Access Form

Merch Interest Form:

After popular demand, we now have merch! Funds will be used to be used for future merchandise and CADathon prizes. Please fill out the form so we can gauge interest for sales. We are planning on using the Independent Trading IND4000 blanks

Google Docs

FRCDesign.org Merch Drop Interest Form

Final design subject to minor changes*

image697√ó971 43.1 KB

image658√ó938 55.9 KB

The Stage 1A rework is now live on the main site! The methodology behind the changes will be posted tomorrow.

The Stage 2 update plans will be posted in the following days.

FRCDesign.org Course Update

After hundreds of hours of testing and development, we‚Äôve updated the Stage 1A and 0 sections of the course! If you are planning on training members soon, do note that this is a significant rework to the initial course structure, so it is important to get an understanding of the update before having students learn through the course.

Stage 0 and 1A Updates

The previous Stage 0, which contained content useful to people new to CAD, was very wordy and often not useful to everyone in its entirety. It‚Äôs been reformatted to 3 sections: New to CAD, New to Onshape, and Required Course Tools. The section you start at depends on your level of experience going into the course; however, everyone needs to go through required course tools. Wording was made more concise and navigation of Onshape was integrated into the new 1A to make it relevant as they learn it.

As mentioned in the previous post, we‚Äôve replaced all of the content in Stage 1A Onshape fundamentals with a reworked course that significantly lowers the barrier to entry for CAD while helping student learn more effectively. The reworked 1A enables students to learn CAD in an FRC context, build part studio and constraint reasoning skills, and finish the section comfortable with the tools they‚Äôll use most frequently for FRC.

Additionally, we wanted to ensure that students always use information that they learned immediately to ensure that everything stayed consistently relevant.

For Educators (IMPORTANT)

We heavily recommend educators to learn through the course before using it as training or curriculum material for students

The structure of the new stage 0 and 1A primarily focuses on FRCDesign. org-specific workflows (See the following section for details), so we recommend that new students not skip these sections, even if they have prior CAD experience. The course is designed so that students with prior CAD experience are primarily focused on picking up workflows quickly, while new students build proficiency and practice in these skills at their own pace.

This course is designed to be self-paced for a flipped classroom if used in a classroom environment. We strongly advise against standard pacing or a lecture-style format, as they do not align with the way students develop skills and learn.

An essential part of the learning process involves struggling with and solving problems. If students are walked through the course before their skills are developed through the problem-solving process, scaffolds will be removed too early, which will lead to a cognitive load spike due to insufficient automation and practice of skills. This will lead to slower long-term progress and more frustration for the learner and educator. This does not mean that a student should not get help, but instead, you should monitor your students and step in if they are struggling for a longer than expected time on a problem.

Please note that this section is based on a single document, with no accompanying solution document. This is done intentionally to reduce the friction between exercises due to the short, interconnected nature of the exercises, and because the learning process is based on the process of experimentation and problem solving to develop knowledge structures and skill proficiency, and not the end product.

Future Updates

We‚Äôll be posting about our future plans on stage 2 and the merch drop soon. Stay posted! If you want a more in depth dive about the 1A changes and design process, we have a writeup below.

Thank you!

Stage 1A Instructional Design Approach and Philosophy:

Click if you want a Deep Dive on the Course Design

As an initial acknowledgement, we chose to update stage 1A instead of working on stage 3 or updating stage 2, as we found the most drop-off and difficulties for beginners at the start of the course, especially with the onshape fundamentals lessons. If a student quits design or becomes demotivated, they won‚Äôt progress through the rest of the course. In contrast, someone who can make it past stage 2 will likely be able to learn independently and remain sufficiently motivated.

This update is not perfect and not as polished as the previous 1A. Still, we believe that this will be more accessible and approachable for beginners and a significant upgrade, in addition to being relevant to the learner from the start without any unintentional gatekeeping mechanisms.

To design the new stage 1A, we worked from the ground up, asking the question, ‚ÄúWhat CAD skills are actually necessary to design a competitive FRC Robot, and what skills require the most fluency as soon as possible?‚Äù In the course, we aimed to ensure that students not only applied the skills but also developed fluency in them, allowing them to focus on the design process rather than the tool.

Additionally, we wanted to avoid any ‚Äúunlearning‚Äù of poor habits or practices. As a result, we aimed to learn the best practices and optimal workflow as soon as possible to minimize confusion for students. As a result, the goals were:

  1. Build fluency in the basic, core fundamentals of CAD in a way that a student can comfortably use to solve problems.
  2. Introduce top-down design immediately with best practices without overwhelming the student.
  3. Ensure that everything the student learns is as intuitive and meaningful as possible, and builds on the knowledge they already have.

A core component of stage 1A is building fluency, problem-solving, and reasoning skills about sketches and constraints, as well as the most common actions that a student would take. (box tubes, plates, assembly mates).

For beginners, the problem-solving task-led approach provides a natural amount of practice, enabling them to build integrated practice within a portion of a workflow. As they progress, information about the FRCDesign.org workflow is gradually integrated as they learn CAD, enabling them to avoid feeling overwhelmed while working at a desirable difficulty. At the same time, for people with more proficiency with CAD, this approach allows students to quickly catch up on the workflow, while having just enough practice to understand how to integrate it.

We choose to deliberately integrate the knowledge of sketches and part modeling in a top-down approach to remove the need for a spatial visualization prerequisite, which is common in bottom-up design and CAD courses. By creating basic associations (sketch rectangle = box tube, multiple sketch rectangles = box tubes next to each other), we can use CAD as a form of spatial reasoning scaffolding, while also naturally teaching intentional, parametric CAD. Additionally, this approach removes the need for students to ‚Äúunlearn‚Äù bottom-up design to learn top-down design, which is a common point of difficulty.

We continue to use the box tube-first approach for the whole of stage 1, which allows for proficiency in relational constraints and parametric thinking while reducing the cognitive load for students by having them only keep track of basic values. (1, 2, 4.25) At the same time, we can quickly build spatial thinking skills due to the nature of multi-part studios. We use a mix of intuitive constraints and implicitly taught constraints to ensure that students pick these vital sketching skills smoothly. We can also integrate the origin cube featurescript early, ensuring that students work in a global coordinate system from the start, which allows for a smoother transition to assemblies later.

image1105√ó963 74.7 KB

In section 2, we finally introduce some ‚Äúbasic‚Äù sketch features such as the line tool, tangent constraint, and circles in the context of plate design, maintaining relevance to the box construction phase in section 1. With students already having a proficiency in sketching and basic constraints, they have significantly less information to learn, allowing them to smoothly pick up a commonly used skill in plate design without feeling overwhelmed. We maintain relevance with the usage of gussets and plates, which is built on their initial design of drivetrains and superstructures in section 1.

image1320√ó1006 82.9 KB

Finally, in section 3, we integrate assembly thinking and mate connectors. By utilizing top-down design and multi-body modeling as a cognitive scaffold for assembly, students can easily infer how to create assemblies based on their part studios in a global coordinate system, without overwhelming them due to it being implicitly taught first. Additionally, it enables students to quickly build comfort and proficiency in the assembly menus, maintaining relevance by allowing them to simply ‚Äúadd‚Äù fasteners to their previous multi-part studios.

In technical terms, utilizing generative and implicit learning, we balance cognitive load by introducing declarative and procedural concepts gradually with short, whole-task activities directly applying robot design to ensure all learning is meaningful and intuitive. Students quickly master CAD software and robot design by building the concepts on top of one another in interleaved settings, while the application-focused methods maintain relevance and engagement. The activities are scaffolded to keep students in the upper levels of Bloom‚Äôs Taxonomy to promote higher order learning consistently using CAD as a cognitive scaffold to manage cognitive load and keep a student at a consistent desirable difficulty. We additionally experiment with limited instructional prompts, and just-in-time information to ensure that information that is introduced is always immediately integrated into a student‚Äôs mental schema.

While we introduce limited metacognitive prompts into this new revision to aid with the skill development process, we hope to further experiment with integrating second-order scaffolds to build self-regulation and metacognition in learners, so by the time they finish the course, they will have built the cognitive habits to transfer into their independent design learning and improvement.

We acknowledge that there are still gaps in content that need to be added during this rework. We also intentionally violate a common design practice by avoiding duplicate parts. However, we believe this tradeoff is justified due to the longer retention and mastery of these skills over shorter periods.

We hope that this new rework will be helpful for your students, and we plan on continuing to update and revise the course to improve the learner experience.

For further reading, we heavily base/apply the design of this rework on Jeroen J. G. van Merri√´nboer‚Äôs and Sweller‚Äôs publications on complex skill learning, cognitive load theory, and schema theory.

Just a heads up for those using teams on onshape.

If someone has access to frc design( or any other apps can do it), in team settings you can push it to individual accounts to help give it to students quickly.

We used FRCDesign extensively in both the team and classroom last season. Thanks to the whole FRCDesign team and your continued work to improve the CAD learning process!

My classroom project was electrically powered catapults using old CIMs, 1x1 tube and 3D printed parts. I liked how my students were able to use system design skills and knowledge of gear ratio selection tools (from FRCDesign.org) to design functioning mechanisms.

Is there an estimate of the minimum and average amount of time it takes a student to work through the exercises?

I‚Äôm sure this varies hugely, but with all the care and research, you might have a guess.

I‚Äôm asking so that I can guide students about when to start and what to expect.

We really appreciate Frcdesign!
Would love to buy some stickers to show it (maybe in addition to hoodies).

Are there subjects which are less relavent for FTC teams?
